metadata.case_name: Writ Petition No. 23 of 1974 (Detenu v. District Magistrate, Varanasi)
metadata.case_number: Writ Petition No. 23 of 1974; Criminal Appeal No. 231 of 1973

facts.text: Petitioner detained under sub-section (iii) of clause (a) of sub-section (1) of section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 by order of District Magistrate, Varanasi dated 3rd September, 1973 to prevent acting prejudicial to maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community.
Grounds of detention served on petitioner on 7th September, 1973.

Ground No. 3: Petitioner and associates charge-sheeted by Mohania Police on 28-11-1966 under section 7 F.C. Act and 125 D.I.R. 1962; case pending before Magistrate, Bhabhua, Bihar, stayed by Patna High Court.

Ground No. 4: Petitioner started firm M/s Shyam Sunder Ashok Kumar in Mohalla Machchodari, P.S. Kotwali, Varanasi in 1966 or 1967 to continue anti-social activities and evade law; minor son Ashok Kumar, brother Shyam Sunder, and family lady as nominal partners; petitioner transacting business for illegal activities.

Ground No. 5: Taking advantage of foodgrain shortage, obtained large quantities of maize, bajra, jawar via firm and smuggled/stored in godown at Mohania, Bihar; detailed sales list on 21-6-1973, 26-6-1973, 7-7-1973, 16-6-1973, 16-7-1973 to numerous persons per cash memos.
Ground No. 6: Persons named in sales (f5) are neither foodgrain Arhatias nor retail shopkeepers at Chandsuli Bazar or village.

Ground No. 7: Sales fictitious to smuggle bajra, jawar, maize to Bihar; bookings from Bihar: 225 bags jawar to Delhi, 116+150+220 bags bajra to Poona, 229 bags jawar to Poona with wagon numbers; consignments to self; signers not found at addresses; petitioner behind transactions.

Ground No. 8: Five trucks (UPF 2039, USF 3253, UPF 2927, USS 7745, UPF 2015) loaded with jawar and bajra apprehended by Mohania Police on 2/3-7-1973 smuggling from UP to Bihar at petitioner's instance.
Ground No. 9: Shortage found on 17-7-1973 by Deputy Regional Marketing Officer, Varanasi: 3 bags rice No.2, 499 bags gram, 70 bags matar, 90 bags dal matar in stock of firm Shyam Sunder Ashok Kumar.
Ground No. 10: Firm not maintained stock register/satta bhari since 1970 for oil-seeds; on 17-7-73 check, 305 bags tisi, 10 bags sarson found.
Ground No. 11: Detaining authority satisfied activities interfere with Essential Commodities Act and Movement Orders prejudicial to supplies/services.
Petitioner applied to Allahabad High Court under Article 226 and s.491 CrPC; dismissed by Division Bench on 26th November, 1973.
Special leave to appeal obtained 19th December, 1973; registered as Criminal Appeal No. 231 of 1973.
State Government confirmed detention order under s.12(1) MISA on 21st November, 1973.
Writ petition No. 23 of 1974 filed before Supreme Court on 20th December, 1973; rule nisi issued 31st January, 1974.
Patna High Court quashed earlier detention order dated 19th July, 1965 based on FIR 11th October, 1964 (same as ground 3) by order 21st August, 1965.
Ground 3 based on FIR 11th October, 1964 by Inspector, Karm Nasha Check Post, Mohania.
Grounds 9 and 10 based on FIR 5th August, 1973, charge-sheet 19th September, 1973 under s.3/7 Essential Commodities Act, pending Varanasi.

legal_issues.text: Whether grounds of detention based on pending criminal prosecutions (grounds 3,8,9,10) vitiate the detention order as detenu cannot make effective representation and authority cannot pursue parallel proceedings.
Whether ground No. 3 is merely descriptive or a substantive ground forming cornerstone of ground No. 4.
Whether delay in disposing representation vitiates detention.
Whether ground No. 8 is non-existent and irrelevant.
Whether remote past incidents form valid basis.

petitioner_arguments.text: Considerable delay in Government disposing of representation vitiates detention order.
Ground No. 8 non-existent and irrelevant, vitiates detention.
Some grounds (3,8,9,10) subject of pending criminal cases sub-judice.
Two remote past incidents basis of some grounds.

respondent_arguments.text: Ground No. 3 merely descriptive, not a ground itself for detention.

court_reasoning.text: Ground No. 3 not merely descriptive but cornerstone of ground 4; based on pending criminal trial in Bihar; identical facts led to quashing of prior detention by Patna HC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ground 3 subject matter of sub-judice criminal trial.

court_reasoning.text: Grounds 3,8,9,10 all based on pending criminal prosecutions; detenu cannot make effective representation without prejudicing criminal defense.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Detenu must have real opportunity for representation under preventive detention.

court_reasoning.text: Detaining authority cannot pursue parallel criminal prosecution and detention on same facts; introduces infirmity.
Distinguished Mohd. Salim Khan as there discharge occurred, but here trials pending; activities watched but grounds sub-judice.
If any ground non-existent/irrelevant, entire detention falls as subjective satisfaction cannot be dissected.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Too many cooks spoil the broth; irrelevant grounds vitiate order.

holdings.text: Detention order invalid as grounds 3,4,8,9,10 based on pending criminal prosecutions in Bihar and UP courts, denying effective representation and involving parallel proceedings.
Grounds referencing pending trials cannot provide valid basis for detention, especially where prior detention quashed on same facts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohd. Salim Khan v. Shri C.C. Bose
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguished as involved discharge, not pending trial; detention valid despite criminal proceedings if no parallel pursuit.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sahib Singh Dugal v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Supports that magistrate discharge does not invalidate detention if activities justify it.

precedents_cited.case_name: Patna High Court orders in C.W.J. Nos. 39 and 40 of 1965
precedents_cited.relevance: Quashed prior detention on same FIR facts as ground 3.

statutes_cited.name: Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for detention order and confirmation; grounds must allow effective representation.

statutes_cited.name: Essential Commodities Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences in grounds 3,9,10; interference prejudicial to supplies.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition and High Court petition.

outcome.summary: Writ petition and appeal allowed; Allahabad High Court judgment set aside; detention order held invalid; rule nisi made absolute; petitioner to be released forthwith unless required in other case.
outcome.relief_granted: Release from detention; Criminal Miscellaneous Petition No. 318 of 1974 allowed; additional papers application rejected.

key_quotes.text: The detaining authority cannot take recourse to two parallel and simultaneous proceedings nor can take recourse to a ground which is the subject matter of a criminal trial.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on invalidity due to parallel proceedings.

key_quotes.text: Being faced with a criminal prosecution which is pending against him all through, we are clearly of the view that the detenu has not got a proper and reasonable opportunity in accordance with law to make an effective representation.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: As too many cooks spoil the broth so also too many grounds may vitiate an order of detention if any one of them is irrelevant or non-existent.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Analogy for why single bad ground invalidates entire order.
